quickSteps: Verify the source: use bookmarks and confirm the full domain before you compare routes.
Keep roles separate: use a small interaction wallet for swapping and store long-term funds elsewhere.
Avoid broad permissions: don’t approve anything you can’t explain in one sentence.
Stay deliberate: compare routes calmly, then execute the swap without rushing through prompts.
Pause on doubt: if a page feels urgent or odd, close it and retry from a clean browser profile/device.

recoveryDecisionTree.start: You suspect a fake domain, social-engineering prompt, or unsafe swap flow while trying to compare routes

branches.if: You clicked an ad or arrived via a link you don’t fully trust
then: Close the tab and do not continue on the current page
Open the real site from a bookmark or manually typed URL
Re-check the route details (asset, chain, receive address) before proceeding
Avoid any prompts asking for seed phrases or remote access

branches.if: You approved a permission or signed something you didn’t understand
then: Stop interacting with new sites immediately
Move any remaining funds to a fresh wallet if you hold meaningful balances
Audit and revoke unnecessary token approvals from a clean environment
Switch to an interaction-wallet model for future swaps

branches.if: Everything looks legitimate but the swap is delayed
then: Avoid panic-retries across multiple providers at once
Document TXIDs, timestamps, and the route/provider you selected
Wait for normal confirmations, then check status via an explorer
Use only official support channels; ignore unsolicited DMs

riskNotes: Many swap incidents start before the chain: ad traps, lookalike domains, and urgent fake prompts.
A privacy-first comparison layer can reduce passive tracking, but it does not make on-chain activity invisible.
Never share seed phrases, private keys, or accept remote-access requests from “support”.
Using an interaction wallet limits blast radius if a swap session goes wrong.
